author: eth2_gitter_bot
content:
<ethDreamer> I would greatly appreciate if anyone can answer any of these questions:

Vitalik's [Eth2 shard chain simplification proposal](https://notes.ethereum.org/@vbuterin/HkiULaluS#Eth2-shard-chain-simplification-proposal) lowers the initial shard count from 1024 to 64. Speaking on the [Chain Reaction Podcast](https://fiftyonepercent.podbean.com/e/vitalik-buterin-eth-20-driven-by-simplified-sharding-optimistic-rollups-and-native-cross-shard-communications/) Vitalik indicated that this was motivated by available CPU power on commodity hardware. This leaves me with 3 questions:

1.  Does the mean CPU is the scaling bottleneck under this latest design?
2.  Assuming CPU power continues to scale, what will be the next bottleneck?
3.  When (meaning at what shard count) will we reach that next bottleneck?

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <mratsim> I think the unknowns for scaling lie in the aggregation protocol.

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <mratsim> Verifying signature is costly and dominates the time in most client at the moment (though we are only starting to optimize it)

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <mratsim> But with the crypto curve chosen we can aggregate multiple signatures and verify them at once, the big questions are where, when who?
